{"uri": "8184481620", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "01:20:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T01:20:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T01:18:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9647058844566345, "url": "https://www.virginislandsdailynews.com/ap/national/record-breaking-us-heat-wave-scorches-the-midwest-and-northeast-bringing-safety-measures/article_71a310fb-5e6e-59af-976e-c61de78c36bf.html", "title": "Record-breaking US heat wave scorches the Midwest and Northeast, bringing safety measures", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit (36.1 degrees Celsius). Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F (37.7 C) at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn Massachusetts, the 911 system was disrupted for nearly two hours Tuesday afternoon as the heat and humidity made it feel over 95 degrees in places. The state's Executive Office of Public Safety and Security said in a post on X that the cause of the outage is under investigation.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches (51 centimeters) was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus. Michael Hill in Albany, New York, contributed.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather", "source": {"uri": "virginislandsdailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8184396220", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:33:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:33:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:28:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9607843160629272, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/6/18/record-breaking-us-heat-wave-scorches-the-midwest-and-northeast-bringing-safety-measures", "title": "Record-breaking US heat wave scorches the Midwest and Northeast, bringing safety measures", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit (36.1 degrees Celsius). Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F (37.7 C) at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches (51 centimeters) was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. {"uri": "2024-06-394734873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:06:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:06:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:50:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9529411792755127, "url": "https://www.rocketcitynow.com/article/news/nation-world/hot-and-humid-weather-as-summer-heat-wave-rolls-in/507-8f872335-312d-4dab-b3bb-cdf341a0b477", "title": "Weather around the US turns hot and humid as summer heat wave rolls in", "body": "Humans, pets and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to keep cool to protect them from the heat.\n\nTOLEDO, Ohio -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\n___\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. Michael Hill in Albany, New York, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.", "source": {"uri": "rocketcitynow.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "rocketcitynow.com"}, "authors": [], (Don Campbell/The Herald-Palladium via AP)\n\nTOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that today's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England today and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for today out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. Today will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on today and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\n___\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. {"uri": "8184355659", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "22:45:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T22:45:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T22:35:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/news/national/heat-wave-scorches-midwest-and-northeast-with-record-breaking-temperatures/article_82ed5ee6-2db8-11ef-87e7-cb9d0bb12849.html", "title": "Heat wave scorches Midwest and Northeast with record-breaking temperatures", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair because of temperatures expected to reach the upper 90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit. Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that {"uri": "8184418975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "00:00:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T00:00:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:59:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.centralmaine.com/2024/06/18/record-breaking-u-s-heat-wave-scorches-the-midwest-northeast/", "title": "Record-breaking U.S. heat wave scorches the Midwest, Northeast", "body": "Yezica Jimenez, 16, from left, Luzmaria Celis, 13, and Sandra Cortez stand under a water barrel at the splash pad inside Waterfront Park in Louisville, Ky., on Tuesday. Louisville is expected to have sustained temperatures in the 90's all week. Sam Upshaw Jr./Courier Journal via AP\n\nTOLEDO, Ohio -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nIn Maine, temperatures are expected to reach the mid-90s in Portland on Wednesday and Thursday. Other parts of the state, including Lewiston, Augusta and Bangor, are under an excessive heat warning - it will feel as hot as 105 degrees in some of those areas.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nA food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves - abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days - since 1936.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit. Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn Massachusetts, the 911 system was disrupted for nearly two hours Tuesday afternoon as the heat and humidity made it feel over 95 degrees in places. The state's Executive Office of Public Safety and Security said in a post on X that the cause of the outage is under investigation.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches (51 centimeters) was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nPress Herald Staff Writer Sara Coughlin contributed to this report.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\n\" Previous\n\nIsrael says Rafah attack near completion, in potential shift for war\n\nNext \"\n\nThe shooter who killed 5 at a Colorado LGBTQ+ club pleads guilty {"uri": "8184394498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:26:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:26:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:25:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/jun/18/record-breaking-us-heat-wave-scorches-the-midwest/", "title": "Record-breaking US heat wave scorches the Midwest and Northeast, bringing safety measures", "body": "Sam Upshaw Jr. / Courier Journal via AP\n\nYezica Jimenez, 16, from left, Luzmaria Celis, 13, and Sandra Cortez stand under a water barrel at the splash pad inside Waterfront Park in Louisville, Ky., on Tuesday, June 18, 2024. Louisville is expected to have sustained temperatures in the 90's all week.\n\nBy John Seewer and Patrick Orsagos, Associated Press\n\nTuesday, June 18, 2024 | 4:13 p.m.\n\nTOLEDO, Ohio -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit (36.1 degrees Celsius). Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F (37.7 C) at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches (51 centimeters) was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\n___\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus. {"uri": "8185383754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:22:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:22:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:21:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/493112/Early-blast-of-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-the-US", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across the US - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Children run through water provided by the Benton Harbor Department of Public Safety during Spray and Play on Tuesday, June 18, 2024, at City Center Park in downtown Benton Harbor, Mich. (Don Campbell/The Herald-Palladium via AP)\n\nA blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185346991", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:57:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:57:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:57:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/news/early-blast-of-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-the-us/", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across the US - Breitbart", "body": "A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer has put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urge people to take precautions\n\nEarly blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across the USBy JOHN SEEWER and PATRICK ORSAGOSAssociated PressThe Associated PressTOLEDO, Ohio\n\nTOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\n___\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. Michael Hill in Albany, New York, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breitbart"}, "authors": [{"uri": Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\n___\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. {"uri": "2024-06-394221693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:25:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:25:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:02:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/national/early-blast-of-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-the-us/article_0326e0b2-95d4-5504-a108-0b04893a9be3.html", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across the US", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. Michael Hill in Albany, New York, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather", "source": {"uri": "wboc.com", {"uri": "8184412819", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:51:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:51:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:50:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/18/record-breaking-u-s-heat-wave-scorches-the-midwest-and-northeast-bringing-safety-measures/", "title": "Record-breaking U.S. heat wave scorches the Midwest and Northeast", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nIn Maine, temperatures are expected to reach the mid-90s in Portland on Wednesday and Thursday. Other parts of the state, including Lewiston, Augusta and Bangor, are under an excessive heat warning - it will feel as hot as 105 degrees in some of those areas.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nA food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves - abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days - since 1936.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit. Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn Massachusetts, the 911 system was disrupted for nearly two hours Tuesday afternoon as the heat and humidity made it feel over 95 degrees in places. The state's Executive Office of Public Safety and Security said in a post on X that the cause of the outage is under investigation.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches (51 centimeters) was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nPress Herald Staff Writer Sara Coughlin contributed to this report.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nComments are not available on this story.\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\n\" Previous\n\nIsrael says Rafah attack near completion, in potential shift for war filed under: portland maine Related Stories {"uri": "8184413646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:52:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:52:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:51:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/ap/national/record-breaking-us-heat-wave-scorches-the-midwest-and-northeast-bringing-safety-measures/article_e93aa79c-28b9-52a2-8052-d2fd97e8c8f3.html", "title": "Record-breaking US heat wave scorches the Midwest and Northeast, bringing safety measures", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nOfficer driving truck in deadly beach accident is Horry's longtime beach safety director Carnival's Charleston-based cruise ship gives passengers a 30-minute warning 5 arrested after more than 200 cars take over street near Cherrydale On Father's Day, former SC Governor Nikki Haley says goodbye to her dad Owner of a beloved boiled peanut trailer is fighting for his life and land in Charleston SC Showrunner cuts ties with Miss USA amid claims of abusive management Gamecock Nyck Harbor's Olympic dream must wait 'She was beloved': Friends, family remember Myrtle Beach woman killed by police vehicle Hardeeville nurse gets 18 months probation, fine for assaulting teen on plane SC Freedom Caucus takes down 2 GOP House leader allies. But sides largely stalemate.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit (36.1 degrees Celsius). Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F (37.7 C) at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches (51 centimeters) was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus. {"uri": "8185317508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:37:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:37:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:37:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.wbrz.com/news/early-blast-of-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-the-us/", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across the US", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. {"uri": "8185751352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:51:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:51:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:50:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/19/early-blast-of-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-the-u-s/", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across the U.S.", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\nEven before noon on Wednesday, the heat index in Maine soared to 100 degrees in Portland and Waterville with 103 in Sanford and Fryeburg, according to News Center Maine meteorologist Jason Nappi. Thursday is forecast to be just as hot.\n\nJerome Quirion of Sherbrooke, Quebec, Canada, wades back to shore after venturing into the chilly Atlantic Ocean with his 18-month-old daughter, Amelie, while vacationing, in Old Orchard Beach on Tuesday. Robert F. Bukaty/Associated Press\n\nAcross the U.S., people and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves - abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days - since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. Michael Hill in Albany, New York, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines Portland won't be spared as heat wave sweeps Maine\n\nSend {"uri": "2024-06-394240170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:48:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:48:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:02:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/early-blast-of-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-the-us/article_89456f02-bd28-543b-9a98-3d88eeceb8c2.html", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across the US", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. Michael Hill in Albany, New York, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather\n\nMore from this section\n\nSecured Signing Scales Up with Strategic Leadership and Global Expansion\n\nLatinx Festival on L. Ron Hubbard Way Celebrates Diversity, Community, Friendship and Empowerment\n\nDovenmuehle's Above Average Residential Mortgage Loan Primary Servicer Ranking Affirmed by S&P Global Rankings",
