{"uri": "2024-06-395095702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:23:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:23:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:05:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.sunjournal.com/2024/06/19/early-blast-of-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-the-u-s/", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across the U.S.", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\nEven before noon on Wednesday, the heat index in Maine soared to 100 degrees in Portland and Waterville with 103 in Sanford and Fryeburg, according to News Center Maine meteorologist Jason Nappi. Thursday is forecast to be just as hot.\n\nJerome Quirion of Sherbrooke, Quebec, Canada, wades back to shore after venturing into the chilly Atlantic Ocean with his 18-month-old daughter, Amelie, while vacationing, in Old Orchard Beach on Tuesday. Robert F. Bukaty/Associated Press\n\nAcross the U.S., people and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves - abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days - since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. Michael Hill in Albany, New York, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nRelated Headlines\n\nPortland won't be spared as heat wave sweeps Maine\n\nModify your screen name\n\nJoin the Conversation\n\nPlease sign into your Sun Journal account to participate in conversations below. "https://www.sunjournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/11/2024/06/Severe_Weather_Maine_58519_71aa4d-1718823953.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9663398", "eventUri": "eng-9663398", {"uri": "8186735030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:37:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:37:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:36:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees (34.4 C) compared with 89 (31.6 C), according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8186185657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "02:09:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T02:09:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T02:08:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.10news.com/weather/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday. (Scripps News)\n\nA blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees Fahrenheit on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June, and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, who added that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid-July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities amid limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy,\" said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday, making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico killed two people and damaged 1,400 buildings Tuesday in the area of a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nRelated stories:\n\nMore than 75 million Americans face extreme heat, while 2 states brace for snow\n\nTropical {"uri": "8184684156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:18:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:18:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:16:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-early-blast-of-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-the-us-6048243.html", "title": "World News | Early Blast of Heat and Humidity Leaves Millions Sweltering Across the US | LatestLY", "body": "Toledo (US), Jun 19 (AP) A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nAlso Read | Amazon Fined Nearly USD 6 Million for Labour Law Violation in US, Authorities Say E-Commerce Giant Didn't Provide Employees Written Notice of Quotas To Follow.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAlso Read | Apple Faces Lawsuit After UK Businessman's Wife Reads Deleted iMessage Chats With Sex Workers, Leading to Hefty Divorce.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. {"uri": "2024-06-395693116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:44:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:44:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/jun/20/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life/", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and today, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100-105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and today, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open, but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43--year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis on Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan today and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nPeople sit at a light rail stop as the temperature hits 104-degrees Monday, June 17, 2024, in Phoenix. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin)\n\nPeople cool down at the Green River Timber Crib Dam in Guilford, Vt., on Wednesday, June 19, 2024. (Kristopher Radder /The Brattleboro Reformer via AP)\n\nA woman wearing a sweatshirt on her head to protect herself from the sun walks across a crosswalk in downtown Washington, Wednesday, June 19, 2024. High temperatures are expected to stay in the 90s in the nation's capital for the rest of the week as a heat wave builds into the Northeast. {"uri": "2024-06-395212844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:42:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:42:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:39:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/heatwave-making-life-miserable-for-millions-9403219/", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "Millions of people were left sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nA blistering heatwave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees (34.4 C) compared with 89 (31.6 C), according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid. \"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly. \"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August. \"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nAlso Read: | But it's only June: an early blast of heat grips much of the US\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston. \"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed. That affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries.\n\nAlso Read: | Much of US braces for extreme weather, from southern heat wave to possible snow in the Rocky Mountains\n\nThe center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week.\n\nThe city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday. Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nAlso Read: | All the ways a hotter planet makes us sicker\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather. High humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning. \"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the US saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season.\n\nWildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, "authors": [{"uri": A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. {"uri": "2024-06-395219074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:55:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:55:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_58c28c4d-d8bc-592b-8c16-4e8a608c5bde.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "A heat wave is breaking temperature records across central and eastern US states, with 80 million people under heat advisories. Cities like New York, and Chicago have surpassed decades-old temperature records, with New York activating its Emergency Operations Center. Public cooling centers a...\n\nBOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer\n\n1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets.\n\n2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential.\n\n3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it.\n\n4. Avoid hot pavement.\n\n5. Provide shaded areas.\n\n6. Swim safely.\n\n7. Adjust your routine.\n\n8. {"uri": "8184693270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:28:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:28:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:24:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13545585/Early-blast-heat-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-US.html", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across...", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) - A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nChildren run through water provided by the Benton Harbor Department of Public Safety during Spray and Play on Tuesday, June 18, 2024, at City Center Park in downtown Benton Harbor, Mich. (Don Campbell/The Herald-Palladium via AP)\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo\u00b4s executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it\u00b4s this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I\u00b4m hoping that we\u00b4re going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer\u00b4s market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves - abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days - since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It\u00b4s extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago\u00b4s Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we\u00b4re doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state\u00b4s historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus, Ohio. Michael Hill in Albany, New York, and Lisa Baumann in Bellingham, Washington, contributed.\n\nFollow AP\u00b4s coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather\n\nBest friends Anna Labelle, left and Frankie Russell got creative Tuesday morning, June 18, 2024, to help stay cool in Labelle's backyard in Auburn, Maine, as the temperature began to climb. (Russ Dillingham/Sun Journal via AP)\n\nYezica Jimenez, 16, from left, Luzmaria Celis, 13, and Sandra Cortez stand under a water barrel at the splash pad inside Waterfront Park in Louisville, Ky., on Tuesday, June 18, 2024. Louisville is expected to have sustained temperatures in the 90's all week. (Sam Upshaw Jr./Courier Journal via AP)\n\nSerena Porter, 9, stays cool as she runs through water provided by the Benton Harbor Department of Public Safety during Spray and Play on Tuesday, June 18, 2024, at City Center Park in downtown Benton Harbor, Mich. The heat wave that has been hitting much of the United States is now moving into the Northeast. (AP Photo/Robert F. Bukaty)\n\nDavid Walker and Lisa Lampe park their van down by the river and under 64 to remain cool in the heat, Tuesday, June 18, 2024, in Louisville, Ky. {"uri": "8185434563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:54:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:54:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:54:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/world-news/20240619/early-blast-heat-and-humidity-leaves-millions-sweltering-across-us", "title": "Early blast of heat and humidity leaves millions sweltering across US", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- A blast of heat and humidity in the Midwest and Northeast days before the official start of summer put a wet blanket on outdoor activities from festivals to sports camps as officials urged people to take precautions.\n\nCities that opened cooling centres this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday means some public libraries, senior centres and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organisation that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city cancelled a weekly fitness event and a neighbouring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s (about 35 C). A food bank in upstate New York cancelled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York cancelled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nPeople are also reading... PBS Appalachia studio to open late fall inside Hard Rock Man arrested after driving vehicle with deceased female in rear seat Blueberries abound at the Berry Patch Farm TBI investigating fatal officer-involved shooting Local Briefs: Laisure transfers to Science Hill; Honaker's Lowe earns all-state soccer honors Local Briefs: Eastside's Clay earns Class 1 softball player of the year award Forbes Hubbard stepping down from city school board Bristol Casino reports second highest revenue month since opening Charges filed following pursuit, head-on collision in Wise County\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair because of temperatures expected to reach the upper 90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit. Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 degrees at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that {"uri": "8186055897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:14:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:14:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T23:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://dailyprogress.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_f252bea4-aa10-5e8a-9f99-69b7f15daaef.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer 1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets. 2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential. 3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it. 4. Avoid hot pavement. 5. Provide shaded areas. 6. Swim safely. 7. Adjust your routine. 8. {"uri": "8187362109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:12:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:12:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:10:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.insurancejournal.com/news/midwest/2024/06/20/780557.htm", "title": "Heat Wave Sweeps Across Midwest and Northeast, Bringing Safety Measures", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit (36.1 degrees Celsius). Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F (37.7 C) at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days. She also said admission and parking fees at state parks, pools and beaches would be waived on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn Massachusetts, the 911 system was disrupted for nearly two hours Tuesday afternoon as the heat and humidity made it feel over 95 degrees in places. The state's Executive Office of Public Safety and Security said in a post on X that the cause of the outage is under investigation.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches (51 centimeters) was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\n___\n\nOrsagos reported from Columbus. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm,\" Fox said.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front will bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nThat relief won't come in time for the closure of all but one cooling center in Chicago on the Juneteenth holiday.\n\n\"It's extremely alarming that we are shrinking our cooling centers in the middle of a heat wave,\" state Rep. Lindsey LaPointe told The Chicago Sun-Times. LaPointe represents Chicago's Northwest Side and advocates for people who do not have permanent shelter and other vulnerable populations.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities {"uri": "2024-06-394371665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:00:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:00:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.fultonsun.com/news/2024/jun/18/record-breaking-us-heat-wave-scorches-the-midwest/", "title": "Record-breaking U.S. heat wave scorches the Midwest and Northeast, bringing safety measures", "body": "TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) -- Stifling heat blanketed tens of millions across United States on Tuesday, forcing people and even zoo animals to find ways to cool down as summer arrives in what promises to be a sweltering week.\n\nExtreme heat alerts stretched from Iowa to Ohio and even into the upper reaches of Michigan on Tuesday, canceling youth sports camps, nature walks and festivals across the region. The National Weather Service said the dangerous heat wave was expected to make its way across the country and into Maine until at least Friday.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh foods in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels for their workers in case of overheating and packed cold water to stay hydrated.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nIn Toledo, Ohio, the city canceled a weekly fitness event and a neighboring suburb called off a street fair as temperatures reached the mid-90s. A food bank in upstate New York canceled deliveries for Wednesday out of concern for its staff and volunteers.\n\nSchools in New York canceled field trips Tuesday to the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, where workers turned on water misters for visitors and the animals. Elephants and other animals were getting chunks of ice in their pools, said Ted Fox, the zoo's executive director.\n\n\"Most of the species love them,\" Fox said. \"Even the tigers love to lick the ice and put their heads on them when it's this warm.\"\n\nCities that opened cooling centers this week advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat will be closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth holiday.\n\nThe blast of extreme temperatures before the official start of summer came a little too early for many.\n\n\"This is hot for just moving in to summer, so I'm hoping that we're going to see the downward trend in the temperature here soon because this is a warm one,\" said Krista Voltolini, who was selling produce at a farmer's market in Columbus.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit. Hot and muggy conditions will continue this week with peak heat indexes near 100 F at times, the National Weather Service in Chicago said in a post on the social platform X.\n\nMuch of the Midwest and Northeast were under heat warnings or watches, with officials urging people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul activated the National Guard to assist in any heat emergencies that develop over the next several days.\n\n\"This is a time of significant risk, and we're doing our best to make sure that all lives are protected,\" Hochul said Tuesday.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nWhile much of the U.S. swelters, late-season snow was forecast for the northern Rockies, with parts of Montana and north-central Idaho under a winter storm warning into Tuesday. As much as 20 inches was predicted for higher elevations around Glacier National Park.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nJerome Quirion of Sherbrooke, Quebec, Canada, wades back to shore after venturing into the chilly Atlantic Ocean with his 18-month-old daughter, Amelie, while vacationing, in Old Orchard Beach, Maine, Tuesday, June 18, 2024. The heat wave that has been hitting much of the United States is now moving into the Northeast. (AP Photo/Robert F. Bukaty)\n\nChildren run through water provided by the Benton Harbor Department of Public Safety during Spray and Play on Tuesday, June 18, 2024, at City Center Park in downtown Benton Harbor, Mich. (Don Campbell/The Herald-Palladium via AP)\n\nDavid Walker and Lisa Lampe park their van down by the river and under 64 to remain cool in the heat, Tuesday, June 18, 2024, in Louisville, Ky. (Scott Utterback/Courier Journal via AP)\n\nWorkmen with the Architect of the Capitol office, perform maintenance on the irrigation system in a park near the Senate, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, June 18, 2024. Extreme heat is expected to break records for tens of millions of people in the United States this week. (AP Photo/J.
