{"uri": "8186036553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:48:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:48:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:46:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://journalnow.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_3ca4ecb5-9369-5159-ba86-9c1f1609d271.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and {"uri": "2024-06-395106042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:38:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:38:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:21:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/article_390e1843-d0d7-520d-ae96-f75993bbb61f.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "Visitors wear sun hats, sunglasses, and carry an umbrella to protect themselves from the sun as they sightsee near the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, June 19, 2024. High temperatures are expected to stay in the 90s in the nation's capital for the rest of the week as a heat wave builds into the Northeast.\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", {"uri": "8185955160", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:10:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:10:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:08:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/news/national/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/article_a3700194-2989-538c-a557-d35a4e989f4f.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees (34.4 C) compared with 89 (31.6 C), according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather", "source": {"uri": "santamariatimes.com", {"uri": "2024-06-396202000", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:57:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:57:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:50:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.aol.com/millions-sweating-heat-wave-nears-155004522.html", "title": "Millions sweating it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "Millions sweating it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine\n\nNICK PERRY and HOLLY RAMER\n\nJune 20, 2024 at 5:50 PM\n\nCONCORD, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. The city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index Wednesday, warmer than Miami.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nIt was already close to 90 degrees in Concord, New Hampshire, Thursday morning as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nSome options for relief were limited by Juneteenth activities: Cities that opened cooling centers advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat were closed for Wednesday's holiday.\n\nIn Indianapolis, a daytime homeless service center picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. Horizon House served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\n___\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", {"uri": "8185925997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:40:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:40:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:40:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.centralmaine.com/2024/06/19/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "Jerome Quirion of Sherbrooke, Quebec, Canada, wades back to shore after venturing into the chilly Atlantic Ocean with his 18-month-old daughter, Amelie, while vacationing, in Old Orchard Beach on Tuesday. Robert F. Bukaty/Associated Press\n\nTOLEDO, Ohio -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\nRelated Heat wave trips up power plants, prompting New England grid operator to issue warning\n\nEven before noon on Wednesday, the heat index in Maine soared to 100 degrees in Portland and Waterville with 103 in Sanford and Fryeburg, according to News Center Maine meteorologist Jason Nappi. Thursday is forecast to be just as hot.\n\nWe usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPeople walk through the wading pool at Deering Oaks Park in Portland on Wednesday. Mainers looked for ways to deal with a heat wave on Wednesday which brought temperatures in the high 80s with high humidity. Gregory Rec/Staff Photographer\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves - abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days - since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nAnthony Izaguirre in Albany, New York, and Isabella Volmert in Indianapolis contributed to this story.\n\nCopy The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nIowa DCI: Wall Lake trucker David Schultz's death 'not a homicide' Jefferson, S.D. dad shares secret to fatherhood on Father's Day celebration Lost and found: How Arnolds Park got a miniature train back after more than 50 years Perley to step down as Thompson CEO; Beaulieu to take over Man dies in standoff with authorities in Sac County Former Sioux City hotel under renovation, to become high-rise senior housing this year Omaha ballpark seeks to ban two Texas A&M fans who were kicked out of College World Series game Tyson Foods heir suspended as CFO after second alcohol-related arrest Boat speed rule imposed on Okoboji lakes in wake of heavy rains, storms that also led to wastewater discharges Sioux City man pleads not guilty of manslaughter Our Opinion: WITCC settlement in human trafficking case raises more questions Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for June 17, 2024 Chainsaw sculptures among latest upgrades to Sioux City's historic Hubbard Park Top area softball performers: RSM last unbeaten team; Mentzer, Moreau swinging hot bats Man pleads not guilty in Sioux City fatal hit and run\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the midto upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to {"uri": "2024-06-396155472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:13:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:13:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:50:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-06-20/millions-sweating-it-out-as-heat-wave-nears-peak-from-midwest-to-maine", "title": "Millions Sweating It Out as Heat Wave Nears Peak From Midwest to Maine", "body": "CONCORD, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. The city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index Wednesday, warmer than Miami.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nIt was already close to 90 degrees in Concord, New Hampshire, Thursday morning as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nSome options for relief were limited by Juneteenth activities: Cities that opened cooling centers advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat were closed for Wednesday's holiday.\n\nIn Indianapolis, a daytime homeless service center picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. Horizon House served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-395104774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:37:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:37:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:21:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/article_89456f02-bd28-543b-9a98-3d88eeceb8c2.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "A blistering heat wave stretching from the Midwest to the tip of Maine is leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather\n\nMore from this section\n\nDovenmuehle's Above Average Residential Mortgage Loan Primary Servicer Ranking Affirmed by S&P Global Rankings\n\nLatinx Festival on L. {"uri": "2024-06-396145330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:02:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:02:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:50:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/national/millions-sweating-it-out-as-heat-wave-nears-peak-from-midwest-to-maine/article_e6c0d73d-60bf-5b2e-af23-e6edc8dbe984.html", "title": "Millions sweating it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "A woman wearing a sweatshirt on her head to protect herself from the sun walks across a crosswalk in downtown Washington, Wednesday, June 19, 2024. High temperatures are expected to stay in the 90s in the nation's capital for the rest of the week as a heat wave builds into the Northeast.\n\nCONCORD, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. The city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index Wednesday, warmer than Miami.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nIt was already close to 90 degrees in Concord, New Hampshire, Thursday morning as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nSome options for relief were limited by Juneteenth activities: Cities that opened cooling centers advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat were closed for Wednesday's holiday.\n\nIn Indianapolis, a daytime homeless service center picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. Horizon House served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather", "source": {"uri": "wboc.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8185946819", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:03:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:03:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:02:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/juneteenth-scorching-us-temperatures-humidity-unleash-merciless-blazing-fury-blistering-conditions-plague-millions-101718829719980.html", "title": "Juneteenth: Scorching US temperatures, humidity unleash merciless, blazing fury; blistering conditions plague millions", "body": "A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine, where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees (34.4 C) compared with 89 (31.6 C), according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\nAlso read | India-born H-4 visa holder forced to self-deport from US after 'aging out' from his mother's green card petition\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\nAlso read | Activists spray paint UNESCO heritage site 'Stonehenge' in UK| Video\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. {"uri": "8185943223", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:00:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:00:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:58:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://kion546.com/news/ap-california/2024/06/19/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine - KION546", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees (34.4 C) compared with 89 (31.6 C), according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.", "source": {"uri": "kion546.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KION546"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185894511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:05:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:05:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:04:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/indiana/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/article_f9fd7928-3149-53e5-91c7-ebe7cf8dabb7.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "By MICHAEL CASEY - Associated Press\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-06-395231665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:23:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:23:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_28986cba-9e9c-5ceb-82af-55b50db9f8b9.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "A heat wave is breaking temperature records across central and eastern US states, with 80 million people under heat advisories. Cities like New York, and Chicago have surpassed decades-old temperature records, with New York activating its Emergency Operations Center. Public cooling centers a...\n\nBOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nOwner of Starbeck's Smokehouse opening burger restaurant in Cedar Falls in July College Football: Cedar Falls native, grandson of former Panther basketball assistant coach commits to UNI Car trapped under semitruck in collision on North Elk Run Road Cedar Falls man arrested for alleged theft of electric bikes Deere & Co. to pay $1.1 million in back wages, interest to Black and Hispanic applicants Two transported to hospital Saturday after motorcycle crashed in ditch Greene man airlifted after motorcycle crashes with pickup west of Plainfield Two women charged in counterfeiting operation at Evansdale home Angel Reese says Caitlin Clark gets 'special whistle.' It blew after Reese's blow to Clark's head Nebraska man arrested in Quasqueton cemetery crash Cancer journey strengthens deep bond between Relay for Life honorary survivor, caregiver Several injured in Bremer County crash Rural mail carrier pleads to theft of home improvement store rebates High School Baseball: Cedar Falls' Coonradt making most of opportunities before freshman season at Iowa Waterloo offices closed for Wednesday for Juneteenth; construction at yard waste site\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer\n\n1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets.\n\n2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential.\n\n3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it.\n\n4. Avoid hot pavement.\n\n5. Provide shaded areas.\n\n6. Swim safely.\n\n7. Adjust your routine.\n\n8. Don't leave your pet unattended in the car.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign
