{"uri": "2024-06-395232344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:24:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:24:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_b6f87c6f-2513-512b-8170-14779ec337c4.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "A heat wave is breaking temperature records across central and eastern US states, with 80 million people under heat advisories. Cities like New York, and Chicago have surpassed decades-old temperature records, with New York activating its Emergency Operations Center. Public cooling centers a...\n\nBOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nLincoln teen who drowned Thursday in Holmes Lake identified Reported birth of rare white buffalo calf in Yellowstone park fulfills Lakota prophecy Omaha ballpark seeks to ban two Texas A&M fans who were kicked out of College World Series game Lincoln's two wind turbines to come down next month Report: 2 Nebraska biofuel plants among biggest emitters of toxic pollutants Nebraska volleyball's Harper Murray charged with shoplifting from sporting goods store Jimmy Fallon to Omaha volleyball players during chance meeting in Rome: 'You guys are tall' Recruiting: Nebraska set to host eight official visitors, including offensive lineman from New Zealand 'I ... made sure he didn't die on us:' Lincoln men save friend after hit-and-run 'Knew in my heart': Late-night calls lands Nebraska volleyball its first 2026 commitment Omaha's zoo unveils $21 million orangutan forest exhibit: 'It's a really immersive experience' University of Nebraska will increase tuition, cut positions to close remaining budget shortfall New features, including slides and a treehouse, added to Nebraska state parks this summer Couple allegedly steal car from Grand Island airport after being dropped off by Nebraska State Patrol Dylan Raiola watches brother Dayton throw at Nebraska's Friday Night Lights camp\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer\n\n1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets.\n\n2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential.\n\n3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it.\n\n4. Avoid hot pavement.\n\n5. Provide shaded areas.\n\n6. Swim safely.\n\n7. Adjust your routine.\n\n8. Don't leave your pet unattended in the car.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign {"uri": "2024-06-395221862", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:02:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:02:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://qctimes.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_49d5a534-f270-5909-aa5f-f6a90e2d55f5.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "A heat wave is breaking temperature records across central and eastern US states, with 80 million people under heat advisories. Cities like New York, and Chicago have surpassed decades-old temperature records, with New York activating its Emergency Operations Center. Public cooling centers a...\n\nBOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nCar struck by train Saturday in Davenport after driving around crossing gate Water main break closes intersection in Village of East Davenport until next week IN MEMORY: Steve Tappa, 1966-2024 Apartment building in Davenport given order to vacate Kobe Sushi and Hibachi opens in Davenport YMCA of the Iowa Mississippi Valley reacts to possible loss of North Family building Deere & Co. to pay $1.1 million in back wages, interest to Black and Hispanic applicants Davenport man arrested for allegedly possessing child porn Clinton man sentenced to 255 years in prison for sexually abusing, prostituting and extorting girls Angel Reese says Caitlin Clark gets 'special whistle.' It blew after Reese's blow to Clark's head Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Kobe Sushi, Shameless Chocoholic Name of Rock Island drowning victim released Man arrested after police chase in Quad-Cities Wednesday 12 things to see on the Rock Island Arsenal this summer Woman accused of defrauding Quad-Cities-based business\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer\n\n1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets.\n\n2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential.\n\n3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it.\n\n4. Avoid hot pavement.\n\n5. Provide shaded areas.\n\n6. Swim safely.\n\n7. Adjust your routine.\n\n8. Don't leave your pet unattended in the car.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign {"uri": "8186039801", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:52:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:52:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:51:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_f626f015-5c0d-598b-8e3b-a9b4e5946626.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading... PREP FOOTBALL NOTES: Virginia High vs. John Marshall to occur on gridiron; Richlands has new O.C. in Bubba Edwards; Honaker coach faces legal issues Burger Bar moves customers to a different era EMORY & HENRY ATHLETICS: Sensabaugh has personal investment in new role as E&H AD Board approves exception for Taylors Valley cafe Corner Dog House keeps the tradition going Isaiah 117 House breaks ground for new home in Bristol, Va. PBS Appalachia studio to open late fall inside Hard Rock Man arrested after driving vehicle with deceased female in rear seat Forbes Hubbard stepping down from city school board TBI investigating fatal officer-involved shooting Blueberries abound at the Berry Patch Farm Local Briefs: Laisure transfers to Science Hill; Honaker's Lowe earns all-state soccer honors Local Briefs: Eastside's Clay earns Class 1 softball player of the year award Bristol Casino reports second highest revenue month since opening Charges filed following pursuit, head-on collision in Wise County\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer 1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets. 2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential. 3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it. 4. Avoid hot pavement. 5. Provide shaded areas. 6. Swim safely. 7. Adjust your routine. 8. Don't leave your pet unattended in the car. {"uri": "8185883900", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:54:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:54:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:54:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine-6050443.html", "title": "World News | Scorching Temperatures, Humidity Making Life Miserable for Millions from Midwest to Maine | LatestLY", "body": "Boston, Jun 19 (AP) A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity.\n\nAlso Read | Vladimir Putin's North Korea Visit: Russian President Putin, Kim Jong Un Sign Strategic Partnership Treaty Calling for Mutual Assistance if Either Gets Attacked.\n\nThe region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nAlso Read | Hajj 2024: At Least 550 Die During This Year's Hajj Pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia Amid Intense Heat.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centres this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centres and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbours who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centres during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organisation that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the US saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory. {"uri": "8185871579", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:42:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:42:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:41:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://whdh.com/news/scorching-temperatures-humidity-felt-from-midwest-to-maine/", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity felt from Midwest to Maine - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. {"uri": "8187364360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:14:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:14:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:12:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13551697/Millions-sweating-heat-wave-nears-peak-Midwest-Maine.html", "title": "Millions sweating it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "CONCORD, N.H. (AP) - A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves - abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days - since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. The city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index Wednesday, warmer than Miami.\n\n\"I\u00b4ve seen this maybe one time before where it\u00b4s been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\nLevi Rush does a backflip off an old bridge abutment into the Saco River in Buxton, Maine, Tuesday, June 18, 2024. Hot weather is predicted until the end of the week. (Troy R. Bennett/The Bangor Daily News via AP)\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nIt was already close to 90 degrees in Concord, New Hampshire, Thursday morning as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city\u00b4s 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nSome options for relief were limited by Juneteenth activities: Cities that opened cooling centers advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat were closed for Wednesday\u00b4s holiday.\n\nIn Indianapolis, a daytime homeless service center picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. Horizon House served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We\u00b4re really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nFollow AP\u00b4s coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather\n\nVisitors wear sun hats, sunglasses, and carry an umbrella to protect themselves from the sun as they sightsee near the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, June 19, 2024. High temperatures are expected to stay in the 90s in the nation's capital for the rest of the week as a heat wave builds into the Northeast. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)\n\nA woman wearing a sweatshirt on her head to protect herself from the sun walks across a crosswalk in downtown Washington, Wednesday, June 19, 2024. High temperatures are expected to stay in the 90s in the nation's capital for the rest of the week as a heat wave builds into the Northeast. {"uri": "8185857655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:27:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:27:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:26:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.delcotimes.com/2024/06/19/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. {"uri": "8186052470", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:09:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:09:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T23:08:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_4ecc8395-9d42-563b-8984-2d408ceba0fa.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading... Marion woman charged with sexual exploitation of a child McDowell schools recognizes student for science competition success; staff for dedication McDowell sheriff's office looking for suspect, car in armed robbery case McDowell deputies stop car for traffic violation, find meth in search Don't throw out that mail: many NC families set to receive 'SUN Bucks' to help feed children this summer Update: Runaway teen located Man arrested for stealing vehicle, wallet of man who died in Old Fort McDowell alum Zach Franklin having a solid first half for Winston-Salem Dash McDowell County Schools Alumni Spotlight: Josie Morgan found career in health care Juneteenth Freedom Festival kicks off Saturday Developer seeking federal money for $50 million Clinchfield mill housing project Olive Garden planned for former Fatz Cafe building in Morganton Mission Health Center McDowell welcomes new pediatric surgeon Old Fort could see higher property tax, water, sewer rates; public can weigh in on Monday McDowell leaders look at finding coordinator for trails\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer 1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets. 2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential. 3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it. 4. Avoid hot pavement. 5. Provide shaded areas. 6. Swim safely. 7. Adjust your routine. 8. Don't leave your pet unattended in the car. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\n0 Comments", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8186039710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:52:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:52:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:50:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_bf57ceea-a5cc-53d2-a7ed-5f8ff881ab4a.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading... Iowa DCI: Wall Lake trucker David Schultz's death 'not a homicide' Lost and found: How Arnolds Park got a miniature train back after more than 50 years Jefferson, S.D. dad shares secret to fatherhood on Father's Day celebration Perley to step down as Thompson CEO; Beaulieu to take over Former Sioux City hotel under renovation, to become high-rise senior housing this year Man dies in standoff with authorities in Sac County Omaha ballpark seeks to ban two Texas A&M fans who were kicked out of College World Series game Athlete of the Week: Miller's motor leading the way for West Monona Tyson Foods heir suspended as CFO after second alcohol-related arrest Sioux City man pleads not guilty of manslaughter Our Opinion: WITCC settlement in human trafficking case raises more questions Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for June 17, 2024 Boat speed rule imposed on Okoboji lakes in wake of heavy rains, storms that also led to wastewater discharges Chainsaw sculptures among latest upgrades to Sioux City's historic Hubbard Park Top area softball performers: RSM last unbeaten team; Mentzer, Moreau swinging hot bats\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer 1. {"uri": "8186041976", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:55:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:55:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:54:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_956fa9ca-8921-500d-97e4-67c4cc333f19.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading... CHP: Angwin woman dies after car strikes her on driveway Suspect named in fatal Napa County hit-and-run crash Napa Valley College's new student housing: How much will it cost? The Bird joins Super Duper Burgers in Napa Man charged in Lake Berryessa murder pleads not guilty Man injured in tubing accident in Lake Berryessa Napa High School graduates celebrate an end, and a beginning Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Fired American Canyon High School coach faces more sexual abuse charges Regional Italian pizzas coming to Napa Valley Wildfire smoke prompts Napa County air advisory Update: Sonoma wineries follow Point Fire's progress; air quality alerts to end Tuesday Napa art supply store Color Theory to close Finishing touches underway for Biscuits BBQ in downtown Napa Vintage High School graduates took the journey of their lives\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer 1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets. 2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential. 3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it. 4. Avoid hot pavement. 5. Provide shaded areas. 6. Swim safely. 7. Adjust your routine. 8. Don't leave your pet unattended in the car. {"uri": "2024-06-395152398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:54:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:54:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:21:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/scorching-temperatures-humidity-making-life-miserable-for-millions-from-midwest-to-maine/article_f9fd7928-3149-53e5-91c7-ebe7cf8dabb7.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "Visitors wear sun hats, sunglasses, and carry an umbrella to protect themselves from the sun as they sightsee near the Capitol in Washington, Wednesday, June 19, 2024. High temperatures are expected to stay in the 90s in the nation's capital for the rest of the week as a heat wave builds into the Northeast.\n\nBy MICHAEL CASEY - Associated Press\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nPizza Hut restaurants abruptly close across Northwest Indiana after franchisee is accused of defaulting on payments Family of Crown Point ironworker sues after 100-floot plunge at University of Chicago Hospital, faced with 'life-altering, catastrophic injuries' NWI Business Ins and Outs: True BBQ closed; Birdie's Diner, Next Door at Birdie's, Broad Street Tavern, Whihala Ice Cream, Lenny's Coal-Fired Pizza and Beauty and the Bronze opening Overnight closures of Northwest Indiana's Pizza Huts were years in the making, court records show Downtown, racetrack, Kennedy Avenue projects moving ahead in Schererville Chick-fil-A planning to come to Michigan City Downtown Valparaiso has been named a quiet zone Lake Central outlasts Mooresville to win second state title East Chicago man dies in motor vehicle accident Wednesday, coroner's office says Past president of Sin City Deciples sentenced to 17 years, officials say Second person dies in wake of alleged OWI crash; charge enhanced, records show Franciscan Health building a $185.5 million, five-story hospital addition in Munster More than 200 workers out of work at 15 shuttered Pizza Hut restaurants as chain, franchisee fight in court Pedestrian struck in fatal crash identified by coroner Man dead after being burned Monday in garage fire, officials say\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees (37.7 C to 40.5 C) in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43 -- year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nAn organization that provides produce to areas with limited access to fresh food in Columbus, Ohio, prepared frozen towels and packed cold water for their workers.\n\n\"Hydration is the key,\" said Monique McCoy, market manager for the Local Matters Veggie Van.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nMeanwhile, a fresh batch of tropical moisture was bringing an increasing threat of heavy rain and flash flooding to the central Gulf Coast. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press.
