{"uri": "8187437441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:06:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:06:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:05:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/aikenstandard/news/nation/millions-sweating-it-out-as-heat-wave-nears-peak-from-midwest-to-maine/article_79ea8649-8744-5c7d-9b84-50c35934940a.html", "title": "Millions sweating it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "CONCORD, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. The city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index Wednesday, warmer than Miami.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt too quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nIt was already close to 90 degrees in Concord, New Hampshire, Thursday morning as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nSome options for relief were limited by Juneteenth activities: Cities that opened cooling centers advised that some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat were closed for Wednesday's holiday.\n\nToday's Top Headlines Tractor Supply could be coming to Aiken's Northside Aiken County Council still 'working on the details' of deal to sell old Aiken County Hospital Aiken County Public School District appoints Langston as Director of Teaching and Learning Voting begins for Aiken's Choice 2024 awards Savannah River Site-powered Voyager 1 operating normally again No property tax increase in finalized Aiken County budget for 2024-2025 Peach season demands 'sense of urgency' for Jimmy Forrest and family Aiken Women in Black celebrates 20 years of peace vigils Local eco-friendly initiative removes bags of litter from Aiken nature preserve grounds Deadline to apply for 2025 Masters Tournament tickets is near\n\nIn Indianapolis, a daytime homeless service center picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. Horizon House served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C). A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nFollow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", {"uri": "8185973282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:29:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:29:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:28:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.newser.com/story/351905/millions-endure-scorching-heat-sticky-humidity.html", "title": "Even Maine Has Heated Up This Week", "body": "A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine that rarely experience such conditions this early in the year. The city of Caribou, Maine, 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity, the AP reports. Several residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options that melt too quickly. Over at Moose River Campground, 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet and said such conditions are more common in mid-July or early August. \"I am sweating like crazy, and it's way too hot,\" she said. The dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees Fahrenheit in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper-level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston. \"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside.\" The conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limit options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's Juneteenth holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers, and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed. Officials urged people to limit outdoor activities and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat. {"uri": "8186037371", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:48:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:48:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:47:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/nation-world/weather/weather-forecast-us-extreme-heat-wave/article_238c2c56-56e6-5483-9746-c1af5b8084e2.html", "title": "Scorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine", "body": "BOSTON -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees compared with 89, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\nPeople are also reading... Comedian Pete Davidson shops local ahead of Bloomington shows Rivian announces next set of company-wide layoffs Over 55,000 expected for Tailgate N' Tallboys music fest in Bloomington Bloomington woman in custody on murder charges in rural McLean County shooting Juror dismissed in McLean County murder trial for suspected 'bias' towards defendant First night of Tailgate N' Tallboys canceled due to severe weather Jaylin Bones found guilty in 2022 Bloomington murder Downed power lines and poles cause road closures in McLean County Witness places murder defendant at the scene as Bloomington murder trial continues State: Murder defendant fought Bloomington man over a gun before fatal shooting Videos, phone data show murder defendant's path to Chicago after fatal Bloomington shooting Motorcyclist killed in Tuesday morning crash in Bloomington Ex-Illinois basketball star Terrence Shannon found not guilty in rape trial Michael Mounce survives late push to capture Bloomington-Normal Match Play championship Flick Fact: Today's biggest rip-offs that we all pay?\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nOver at Moose River Campground, about 13 miles from the border, owner Lisa Hall was fixing a cabin faucet amid the sizzling temperatures and said such conditions are more common in mid July or early August.\n\n\"I am sweating like crazy and it's way too hot,\" she said.\n\nThe dangerous temperatures were expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Wednesday and Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday and Saturday, the National Weather Service said. Heat index readings were expected to reach 100 to 105 degrees in many locations.\n\n\"We are seeing a ridge of upper level high pressure, which is bringing all this heat from the southern United States,\" said Kyle Pederson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston.\n\n\"That is just causing lots of hot temperature in the mid- to upper 90s and the heat index to reach over 100. It's just going to make it feel warmer than it is outside,\" he said. \"You will really feel that humidity and feel the heat quicker.\"\n\nThe conditions were expected to scale back some Juneteenth activities and limited options for relief. Cities that opened cooling centers this week advised that Wednesday's holiday meant some public libraries, senior centers and pools where residents could beat the heat would be closed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat affected services in Indianapolis, where Horizon House, a daytime homeless service center, picked up slack from closed cooling centers and food pantries. The center served about 200 people a day this week, but the number jumped to 300 for lunch during its Juneteenth festival. It also gave out roughly 450 bottles of water.\n\n\"Today was downright swampy, \"said Courtney Kay Meyers, director of development and communications. \"We're really struggling to keep up with water and demand for water.\"\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Wednesday and Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.\n\nNew York City beaches were open but public swimming pools there were closed until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public. Public libraries, which have been used as cooling centers during other heat waves, were closed Wednesday because of the Juneteenth federal holiday.\n\nAnne-Laure Bonhomme, a 43-year-old health coach, was visiting sites in New York with her family. \"The humidity is pretty insane,\" she said.\n\nPeople and even zoo animals were forced to find ways to thwart the muggy weather.\n\nHigh humidity lingered over Indianapolis Wednesday making the deceptively cloudy day warm and unenjoyable. Parks and walking trails were sparsely populated despite the holiday.\n\nThe Bennett family considered taking their 7-year-old and 4-month old to the pool or a splash pad on their day off of work, but decided it would still be too warm for the kids. Instead, Kayla and Sarah drove from Muncie to the Indiana State Museum in downtown Indianapolis to visit the indoor exhibits in the air conditioning.\n\n\"We decided to do something inside,\" Kayla said.\n\nA recent study found that climate change is making heat waves move more slowly and affect more people for a longer time. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nChicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees. A cold front was expected to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the National Weather Service in Chicago said.\n\nIn California, wildfires erupted east of San Francisco in the state's historic Gold Country region and in the mountains of northern Los Angeles County after what had been a quiet start to fire season. Wildfires in southern New Mexico damaged 500 buildings Tuesday in a mountain village of 7,000 people that had been evacuated with little time to spare.\n\nEssential dog and cat safety tips for the hottest days of summer 1. Learn the signs of overheating in pets. 2. Keeping your pets hydrated is essential. 3. Grooming keeps your pets cool, but don't overdo it. 4. Avoid hot pavement. 5. Provide shaded areas. 6. Swim safely. 7. Adjust your routine. 8. Don't leave your pet unattended in the car. {"uri": "2024-06-396262389", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:04:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:04:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:26:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://eu.detroitnews.com/story/news/nation/2024/06/20/millions-sweating-heat-wave-nears-peak-midwest-maine/74157642007/", "title": "Millions sweating it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "Squam Lake, N.H. -- A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. In central New Hampshire, Angela Wilcox took her two children and two nephews boating Thursday in search of the coldest swimming spot on Squam Lake, where they've stayed at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps for 16 years.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nCamp workers were delivering large blocks of ice to the cabins for refrigeration. A tradition at the camp for more than a century, the ice is harvested from the lake each winter and then packed with sawdust in an insulated storage hut. The method has kept fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nFurther south in Concord, it was already close to 90 degrees as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life.\n\n\"It sucks,\" the 28-year-old said. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\"\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, was hanging out with some others on a church lawn outside of the city's public library, which was serving as a cooling center. He'd slept nearby the night before and said he was trying to catch the shade without getting kicked out.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available but its public swimming pools don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nSome relief is on the way: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C).\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.", "source": {"uri": "detroitnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Detroit News"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187460835", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:25:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:25:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:23:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2024-06-20/us-heat-wave-14243541.html", "title": "Millions sweat it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "SQUAM LAKE, N.H. -- A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. In central New Hampshire, Angela Wilcox took her two children and two nephews boating Thursday in search of the coldest swimming spot on Squam Lake, where they've stayed at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps for 16 years.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nCamp workers were delivering large blocks of ice to the cabins for refrigeration. A tradition at the camp for more than a century, the ice is harvested from the lake each winter and then packed with sawdust in an insulated storage hut. The method has kept fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nFurther south in Concord, it was already close to 90 degrees as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life.\n\n\"It sucks,\" the 28-year-old said. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\"\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, was hanging out with some others on a church lawn outside of the city's public library, which was serving as a cooling center. He'd slept nearby the night before and said he was trying to catch the shade without getting kicked out.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available but its public swimming pools don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nSome relief is on the way: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.", "source": {"uri": "stripes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Stars and Stripes"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-396242408", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:40:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:40:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:02:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.maryvilleforum.com/news/state_news/millions-sweating-it-out-as-heat-wave-nears-peak-from-midwest-to-maine/article_eb89b1b5-2318-508f-a8b0-c44a13d83bab.html", "title": "Millions sweating it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "SQUAM LAKE, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. In central New Hampshire, Angela Wilcox took her two children and two nephews boating Thursday in search of the coldest swimming spot on Squam Lake, where they've stayed at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps for 16 years.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nCamp workers were delivering large blocks of ice to the cabins for refrigeration. A tradition at the camp for more than a century, the ice is harvested from the lake each winter and then packed with sawdust in an insulated storage hut. The method has kept fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nFurther south in Concord, it was already close to 90 degrees as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life.\n\n\"It sucks,\" the 28-year-old said. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\"\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, was hanging out with some others on a church lawn outside of the city's public library, which was serving as a cooling center. He'd slept nearby the night before and said he was trying to catch the shade without getting kicked out.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available but its public swimming pools don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nSome relief is on the way: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C).\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nRamer reported from Concord, N.H. Associated Press writers from across the country contributed, including Lisa Rathke, Kathy McCormack and Bruce Shipkowski. {"uri": "2024-06-396242519", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:40:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:40:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:02:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/millions-sweating-it-out-as-heat-wave-nears-peak-from-midwest-to-maine/article_f312218b-ed00-58c5-b96a-a30beb39b3b8.html", "title": "Millions sweating it out as heat wave nears peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "A heat wave is moving closer to the breaking point from the Midwest to New England as millions of people sweat it out for another day\n\nSQUAM LAKE, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave extending from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday, with millions of people sweating it out for another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heat wave was expected to peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England on Thursday, and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic on Friday or the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings, which combine temperature and humidity, were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said. Officials warned that record overnight temperatures would prevent natural cooling and allow the heat danger to build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of international scientists said human-caused climate change has dialed up the heat and drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat that's been baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to extreme summer heat in northern New England this year. In central New Hampshire, Angela Wilcox took her two children and two nephews boating Thursday in search of the coldest swimming spot on Squam Lake, where they've stayed at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps for 16 years.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nCamp workers were delivering large blocks of ice to the cabins for refrigeration. A tradition at the camp for more than a century, the ice is harvested from the lake each winter and then packed with sawdust in an insulated storage hut. The method has kept fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nFurther south in Concord, it was already close to 90 degrees as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at the city's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks as the temperature climbed.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life.\n\n\"It sucks,\" the 28-year-old said. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\"\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, was hanging out with some others on a church lawn outside of the city's public library, which was serving as a cooling center. He'd slept nearby the night before and said he was trying to catch the shade without getting kicked out.\n\nOfficials have urged people to limit outdoor activities when possible and to check in with family members and neighbors who may be vulnerable to the heat.\n\nIn New York, state parks have free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available but its public swimming pools don't open until next week. The city has a list of hundreds of air conditioned sites that are free and open to the public.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nSome relief is on the way: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 temperature record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C).\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nRamer reported from Concord, N.H. Associated Press writers from across the country contributed, including Lisa Rathke, Kathy McCormack and Bruce Shipkowski. {"uri": "8187685502", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:44:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:44:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:43:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/nation/as-millions-sweat-out-the-heat-wave-blocks-of-lake-ice-keep-these-campers-cool/article_7f03e3e5-0761-536a-9a69-66e2755e24c6.html", "title": "As millions sweat out the heat wave, blocks of lake ice keep these campers cool", "body": "SQUAM LAKE, N.H. (AP) -- As New England continued to bake in a heat wave Thursday, guests at one campground were keeping their food and beer cold with blocks of ice, harvested months earlier from a frozen lake.\n\nAnd while some relief is expected after Thursday's peak heat in the eastern Great Lakes and New England, the National Weather Service said scorching temperatures will linger across the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic region, and even grow in places, to as much as triple-digit highs in California and Arizona.\n\nOn Squam Lake in central New Hampshire, ice blocks about the size of microwave that had been packed in sawdust since winter were lifted from an insulated storage hut. It's been a tradition at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps for more than a century, keeping fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nAngela Wilcox, who has vacationed at the camp for 16 years, took her children and nephews boating Thursday in search of the lake's coldest swimming spot.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nHeat index readings combining temperature and humidity were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations across the country, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said, and because record overnight temperatures could prevent natural cooling, heat danger could build up indoors.\n\n\"Those without access to reliable air conditioning are urged to find a way to cool down,\" the service said in its forecast.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of scientists said human-caused climate change has drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to summer extremes in the northeastern U.S.\n\nIt was already nearing 90 degrees (32.2 C) in New Hampshire as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at Concord's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nAt Johnson's Dairy Bar in Northwood, Camryn Hildredth tried offer customers an empty dish for that heartbreaking moment when a scoop of rapidly melting ice cream topples out of the cone, but not all would listen.\n\n\"Everybody asks if we have AC. We do not,\" she said. \"It's very hot and we get long lines, so it can get very rough sometimes.\"\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\" the 28-year-old said.\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, joined others in a shady spot on a lawn outside the public library, which was serving as a cooling center.\n\nNew York parks had free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available and while its public swimming pools don't open until next week, the city keeps a list of hundreds of free air-conditioned sites.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nWith much of Indiana broiling in the 90s, highway crews are starting shifts at 6 a.m., two hours earlier than in cooler seasons, and taking more frequent breaks in air-conditioned trucks in between filling potholes and other roadwork, said Kyleigh Cramer, a spokesperson for the Indiana Department of Transportation.\n\n\"They're able to get in those trucks and cool off right then and there because being out on the road is a little bit different than being in an office,\" Cramer said.\n\nSome relief is coming: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C).\n\nRamer reported from Northwood, N.H. Associated Press writers from across the country contributed, including Lisa Rathke, Kathy McCormack, Rick Callahan and Bruce Shipkowski. {"uri": "8185568468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:28:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:28:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/record-heatwave-midwest-northeast-america-national-guard-1914760", "title": "Heat wave strikes early -- record temperatures forecast in maps", "body": "Record temperatures are forecast across the Midwest and Northeast in an early heat wave, with the risk of fatalities so high that the National Guard has been activated in one state to help the public.\n\nRead more: What Is a Health Savings Account?\n\nStretching from Ohio to New York State, temperatures have soared into the triple digits -- and the National Weather Service (NWS) has predicted they will reach as high as 105 degrees in some places.\n\nMaps from the NWS show how record highs could sweep the region. These temperatures are also occurring earlier in the year than normal. For example, Cleveland in Ohio is forecast to be 92 degrees on Wednesday, June 19, yet the average temperature there in mid-July is 84 degrees.\n\nNew York Governor Kathy Hochul has called in the National Guard to assist in heat emergencies over the coming days, and also waived admission and parking fees at state parks, pools, and beaches. She previously activated the National Guard earlier this year in an attempt to combat subway violence.\n\nHochul posted to X, formerly Twitter, on Wednesday: \"It is dangerously hot out there, New York. Remember to hydrate, reduce time outside, and check on neighbors.\"\n\nRead more: Discover the Right Bank for Emergency Funds\n\nIn a previous post, she had warned: \"Extreme heat is the number-one weather-related cause of death in the U.S. Make sure you're prepared.\"\n\nFurther issues surrounding public safety have arisen due to the Juneteenth holiday. What should be a celebration of liberation has led to the holiday closure of several cooling centers and shelters across the Midwest and East Coast. Libraries, senior centers, and pools, which otherwise would be open, have been shut for the holiday, frustrating many.\n\nRead more: Find the Right Type of Savings Account for Your Needs\n\nSchools have canceled outdoor trips, and even tropical animals in zoos are struggling under the oppressive heat. Ted Fox, executive director at the Rosamond Gifford Zoo in Syracuse, said elephants, tigers, and other animals were being given chunks of ice.\n\n\"The tigers love to lick the ice,\" Fox said.\n\nAn official heat wave is when abnormally hot weather lasts for more than two days. The starting temperatures of the heat wave this year have already broken records.\n\nChicago saw a high of 97 degrees on Monday, June 17, breaking a 1957 temperature record. The NWS has reported that Wednesday will be another hot day, but a cold front is expected later in the week to bring relief to areas near Lake Michigan.\n\nThe NWS has published extensive advice to their website on how to cope with extreme temperatures. This advice includes wearing loose-fitting clothing, drinking water even if you're not thirsty, and staying indoors as much as possible.\n\nFor people who cannot stay indoors, they recommend taking plenty of 15-minute breaks, lathering on sunscreen, staying in shade as much as possible, and slowing down.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8187658731", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:17:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:17:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:16:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/national/millions-are-sweating-it-out-as-a-heat-wave-nears-its-peak-from-midwest-to/article_7b3081e5-1302-5e7d-80ba-96fb7b039719.html", "title": "Millions are sweating it out as a heat wave nears its peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "SQUAM LAKE, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday as millions of people sweated out another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service predicted it would peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England Thursday and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic by the weekend, but said oppressive heat will linger or grow over much of the rest of the country, including triple-digit highs in California and Arizona.\n\nHeat index readings combining temperature and humidity were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said, and because record overnight temperatures could prevent natural cooling, heat danger could build up indoors.\n\n\"Those without access to reliable air conditioning are urged to find a way to cool down,\" the service said in its forecast.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of scientists said human-caused climate change has drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to summer extremes in the northeastern U.S. In New Hampshire, Angela Wilcox took her two children and two nephews boating Thursday in search of the coldest swimming spot on Squam Lake, where they've stayed at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps near the town of Holderness for 16 years.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nCamp workers were delivering large blocks of ice to the cabins for refrigeration. A tradition at the camp for more than a century, the ice is harvested from the lake each winter and packed with sawdust in an insulated storage hut. The method has kept fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nIt was already nearing 90 degrees (32.2 C) as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at Concord's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nAt Johnson's Dairy Bar in Northwood on Thursday, Camryn Hildredth tried offer customers an empty dish for that heartbreaking moment when a scoop of rapidly melting ice cream topples out of the cone, but not all would listen.\n\n\"Everybody asks if we have AC. We do not,\" she said. \"It's very hot and we get long lines, so it can get very rough sometimes.\"\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\" the 28-year-old said.\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, joined others in a shady spot on a lawn outside the public library, which was serving as a cooling center.\n\nNew York parks had free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available and while its public swimming pools don't open until next week, the city keeps a list of hundreds of free air-conditioned sites.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nWith much of Indiana broiling in the 90s, highway crews are starting shifts at 6 a.m., two hours earlier than in cooler seasons, and taking more frequent breaks in air-conditioned trucks in between filling potholes and other roadwork, said Kyleigh Cramer, a spokesperson for the Indiana Department of Transportation.\n\n\"They're able to get in those trucks and cool off right then and there because being out on the road is a little bit different than being in an office,\" Cramer said.\n\nSome relief is coming: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C).\n\nRamer reported from Northwood, N.H. Associated Press writers from across the country contributed, including Lisa Rathke, Kathy McCormack, Rick Callahan and Bruce Shipkowski. {"uri": "2024-06-396303199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:52:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:52:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:50:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/20/millions-are-sweating-it-out-as-a-heat-wave-nears-its-peak-from-midwest-to-maine/", "title": "Millions are sweating it out as a heat wave nears its peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "SQUAM LAKE, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday as millions of people sweated out another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service predicted it would peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England Thursday and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic by the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings combining temperature and humidity were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said, and because record overnight temperatures could prevent natural cooling, heat danger could build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of scientists said human-caused climate change has drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to summer extremes in the northeastern U.S. In New Hampshire, Angela Wilcox took her two children and two nephews boating Thursday in search of the coldest swimming spot on Squam Lake, where they've stayed at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps near the town of Holderness for 16 years.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nCamp workers were delivering large blocks of ice to the cabins for refrigeration. A tradition at the camp for more than a century, the ice is harvested from the lake each winter and packed with sawdust in an insulated storage hut. The method has kept fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nIt was already nearing 90 degrees (32.2 C) as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at Concord's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nAt Johnson's Dairy Bar in Northwood on Thursday, Camryn Hildredth tried offer customers an empty dish for that heartbreaking moment when a scoop of rapidly melting ice cream topples out of the cone, but not all would listen.\n\n\"Everybody asks if we have AC. We do not,\" she said. \"It's very hot and we get long lines, so it can get very rough sometimes.\"\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\" the 28-year-old said.\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, joined others in a shady spot on a lawn outside the public library, which was serving as a cooling center.\n\nOfficials have urged people to stay indoors if they can and check on vulnerable family members and neighbors.\n\nNew York parks had free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available and while its public swimming pools don't open until next week, the city keeps a list of hundreds of free air-conditioned sites.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nWith much of Indiana broiling in the 90s, highway crews are starting shifts at 6 a.m., two hours earlier than in cooler seasons, and taking more frequent breaks in air-conditioned trucks in between filling potholes and other roadwork, said Kyleigh Cramer, a spokesperson for the Indiana Department of Transportation.\n\n\"They're able to get in those trucks and cool off right then and there because being out on the road is a little bit different than being in an office,\" Cramer said.\n\nSome relief is coming: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C).\n\n___\n\nRamer reported from Northwood, N.H. Associated Press writers from across the country contributed, including Lisa Rathke, Kathy McCormack, Rick Callahan and Bruce Shipkowski. {"uri": "2024-06-396334459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:33:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:33:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:48:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/millions-are-sweating-it-out-as-a-heat-wave-nears-its-peak-from-midwest-to/article_f312218b-ed00-58c5-b96a-a30beb39b3b8.html", "title": "Millions are sweating it out as a heat wave nears its peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "SQUAM LAKE, N.H. (AP) -- A heat wave from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday as millions of people sweated out another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service predicted it would peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England Thursday and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic by the weekend.\n\nHeat index readings combining temperature and humidity were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said, and because record overnight temperatures could prevent natural cooling, heat danger could build up indoors.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of scientists said human-caused climate change has drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to summer extremes in the northeastern U.S. In New Hampshire, Angela Wilcox took her two children and two nephews boating Thursday in search of the coldest swimming spot on Squam Lake, where they've stayed at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps near the town of Holderness for 16 years.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nCamp workers were delivering large blocks of ice to the cabins for refrigeration. A tradition at the camp for more than a century, the ice is harvested from the lake each winter and packed with sawdust in an insulated storage hut. The method has kept fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nIt was already nearing 90 degrees (32.2 C) as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at Concord's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nAt Johnson's Dairy Bar in Northwood on Thursday, Camryn Hildredth tried offer customers an empty dish for that heartbreaking moment when a scoop of rapidly melting ice cream topples out of the cone, but not all would listen.\n\n\"Everybody asks if we have AC. We do not,\" she said. \"It's very hot and we get long lines, so it can get very rough sometimes.\"\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\" the 28-year-old said.\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, joined others in a shady spot on a lawn outside the public library, which was serving as a cooling center.\n\nOfficials have urged people to stay indoors if they can and check on vulnerable family members and neighbors.\n\nNew York parks had free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available and while its public swimming pools don't open until next week, the city keeps a list of hundreds of free air-conditioned sites.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nWith much of Indiana broiling in the 90s, highway crews are starting shifts at 6 a.m., two hours earlier than in cooler seasons, and taking more frequent breaks in air-conditioned trucks in between filling potholes and other roadwork, said Kyleigh Cramer, a spokesperson for the Indiana Department of Transportation.\n\n\"They're able to get in those trucks and cool off right then and there because being out on the road is a little bit different than being in an office,\" Cramer said.\n\nSome relief is coming: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 record Monday with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C).\n\nRamer reported from Northwood, N.H. Associated Press writers from across the country contributed, including Lisa Rathke, Kathy McCormack, Rick Callahan and Bruce Shipkowski. Follow AP's coverage of weather at https://apnews.com/hub/weather\n\nMore from this section\n\nExplore Monster Hunter Now GPS Spoofing: MocPOGO Launches an Innovative 2024 Update\n\nFloify brings its industry-leading point-of-sale technology to The Mortgage Collaborative as a preferred partner\n\nCritical Defect Rate Declines Five Straight Quarters, Ending 2023 at 1.53%, Per ACES Mortgage QC {"uri": "8187689516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:50:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:50:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:47:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/nation-world/weather/extreme-heat-wave-climate/article_85852b14-b7b4-56c0-9cbe-6263ddeb129e.html", "title": "Millions are sweating it out as a heat wave nears its peak from Midwest to Maine", "body": "SQUAM LAKE, N.H. -- A heat wave from the Midwest to New England moved closer to a breaking point Thursday as millions of people sweated out another day.\n\nThe National Weather Service predicted it would peak in the eastern Great Lakes and New England Thursday and in the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic by the weekend, but said oppressive heat will linger or grow over much of the rest of the country, including triple-digit highs in California and Arizona.\n\nHeat index readings combining temperature and humidity were expected to surpass 100 degrees in many locations, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said, and because record overnight temperatures could prevent natural cooling, heat danger could build up indoors.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\n\"Those without access to reliable air conditioning are urged to find a way to cool down,\" the service said in its forecast.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of scientists said human-caused climate change has drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. saw the greatest number of heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. Hurricane season this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to summer extremes in the northeastern U.S. In New Hampshire, Angela Wilcox took her two children and two nephews boating Thursday in search of the coldest swimming spot on Squam Lake, where they've stayed at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps near the town of Holderness for 16 years.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nCamp workers were delivering large blocks of ice to the cabins for refrigeration. A tradition at the camp for more than a century, the ice is harvested from the lake each winter and packed with sawdust in an insulated storage hut. The method has kept fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nIt was already nearing 90 degrees as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at Concord's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nAt Johnson's Dairy Bar in Northwood on Thursday, Camryn Hildredth tried offer customers an empty dish for that heartbreaking moment when a scoop of rapidly melting ice cream topples out of the cone, but not all would listen.\n\n\"Everybody asks if we have AC. We do not,\" she said. \"It's very hot and we get long lines, so it can get very rough sometimes.\"\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\" the 28-year-old said.\n\nHurlbut, who is experiencing homelessness, joined others in a shady spot on a lawn outside the public library, which was serving as a cooling center.\n\nNew York parks had free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available and while its public swimming pools don't open until next week, the city keeps a list of hundreds of free air-conditioned sites.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nWith much of Indiana broiling in the 90s, highway crews are starting shifts at 6 a.m., two hours earlier than in cooler seasons, and taking more frequent breaks in air-conditioned trucks in between filling potholes and other roadwork, said Kyleigh Cramer, a spokesperson for the Indiana Department of Transportation.\n\n\"They're able to get in those trucks and cool off right then and there because being out on the road is a little bit different than being in an office,\" Cramer said.\n\nSome relief is coming: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan on Thursday and Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 record Monday with a high of 97 degrees.\n\nThe best dehumidifiers to keep you comfortable this summer 1. {"uri": "8187778561", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "22:31:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T22:31:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T22:24:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/as-millions-sweat-out-the-heat-wave-blocks-of-lake-ice-keep-these-campers-cool/article_96b83574-6076-5c35-bb93-97b31bcd749a.html", "title": "As millions sweat out the heat wave, blocks of lake ice keep these campers cool", "body": "SQUAM LAKE, N.H. (AP) -- As New England baked in a heat wave Thursday, guests at one campground were keeping their food and beer cold with blocks of ice harvested months earlier from a frozen lake.\n\nAnd while some relief is expected in the eastern Great Lakes region and New England starting Friday, the National Weather Service said scorching temperatures will linger across the Ohio Valley and Mid-Atlantic region, and even rise in places, including California and Arizona, where they could eclipse 100 degrees (nearly 38 degrees Celsius).\n\nOn Squam Lake in central New Hampshire, ice blocks about the size of microwaves that had been packed in sawdust since winter were lifted from an insulated storage hut. It's been a tradition at the rustic Rockywold Deephaven Camps for more than a century, keeping fresh ice available throughout the summer and into the fall.\n\nAngela Wilcox, who has vacationed at the camp for 16 years, took her children and nephews boating Thursday in search of the lake's coldest swimming spot.\n\n\"This is the hottest it's ever been, especially in June,\" Wilcox said. \"We're kind of shocked.\"\n\nHeat index readings combining temperature and humidity were expected to surpass 100 degrees (37.7 C) in many locations across the country, possibly setting some all-time records, the weather service said, and because record overnight temperatures could prevent natural cooling, heat danger could build up indoors.\n\n\"Those without access to reliable air conditioning are urged to find a way to cool down,\" the service said in its forecast.\n\nIn a study published Thursday, a group of scientists said human-caused climate change has drastically increased the odds of experiencing the killer heat baking the Southwestern United States, Mexico and Central America this month. Last year, the U.S. recorded its most heat waves -- abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days -- since 1936.\n\nOcean waters are warmer as well, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, where the season's first named storm, Alberto, was dumping heavy rain and causing flash flooding along a stretch of the coast from Mexico to Louisiana. This year's hurricane season is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory.\n\nIt's made for an unusually early start to summer extremes in the northeastern U.S.\n\nIt was already nearing 90 degrees (32.2 C) in New Hampshire as John Dupont opened his kettle corn stand at Concord's 50th annual Market Days Festival. He and his daughter set up two fans and were prepared to drape icy towels around their necks.\n\n\"This year is a little challenging because of all the heat. Our kettle gets up to 150,000 BTUs,\" he said.\n\nAt Johnson's Dairy Bar in Northwood, Camryn Hildredth tried to offer customers an empty dish for that heartbreaking moment when a scoop of rapidly melting ice cream topples out of the cone, but not all would listen.\n\n\"Everybody asks if we have AC. We do not,\" she said. \"It's very hot and we get long lines, so it can get very rough sometimes.\"\n\nIn Burlington, Vermont, Jack Hurlbut said he's never been so hot in his life. \"I live in Vermont for a reason, you know what I mean?\" the 28-year-old said.\n\nHurlbut, who is homeless, joined others in a shady spot on a lawn outside the public library, which was serving as a cooling center.\n\nNew York's state parks had free admission Thursday, and select state-run pools and beaches opened early for swimming, Gov. Kathy Hochul said. New York City's beaches were available, and although its public pools don't open until next week, the city keeps a list of hundreds of free air-conditioned sites.\n\n\"The humidity is pretty insane,\" said Anne-Laure Bonhomme, a health coach who was sightseeing in New York with her family.\n\nMany school districts in New Jersey switched to early dismissals as the school year winds down, and at least two rescheduled their high school graduation ceremonies due to concerns about excessive heat and humidity.\n\nWith much of Indiana sweltering, highway crews are starting shifts at 6 a.m., two hours earlier than in cooler seasons, and taking more frequent breaks in air-conditioned trucks in between filling potholes and other roadwork, said Kyleigh Cramer, a spokesperson for the Indiana Department of Transportation.\n\n\"They're able to get in those trucks and cool off right then and there because being out on the road is a little bit different than being in an office,\" Cramer said.\n\nSome relief is coming: A cold front is moving into areas near Lake Michigan later Thursday and on Friday, the weather service said. Chicago broke a 1957 record for June 17 on Monday, with a high of 97 degrees (36.1 C).\n\nRamer reported from Northwood, N.H. Associated Press writers from across the country contributed, including Lisa Rathke, Kathy McCormack, Rick Callahan and Bruce Shipkowski.
